GlooKit.GlooFramework

Class GlooApplication

  • java.lang.Object
    • GlooKit.GlooFramework.KitBit
      • GlooKit.GlooFramework.GlooApplication

  • public class GlooApplication
extends KitBit
    A GlooApplication is a game (or other application) within a GLWF window that handles the game loop for the whole application. It has
    • a window handle, which is a long that is the GLWF identifier
    • an Input, which handles user input from keyboards, mice, and controllers
    • a Room, which is the state that the game is in currently, like the Main Menu, Settings Screen, or a Single-Player Battle
    • children (observers), which are Nooks (and the one Room) that are present in the GlooApplication in the current state.
    • and various settings which can be set by using the GlooApplicationConfiguration class. The config file for a given GlooApplication is named name.cfg, where name is the String passed to the constructor.
    GlooApplication also extends KitBit, as it is the parent of all other KitBits in the application, by virtue of being the parent of all Nooks and Rooms.

    A GlooApplication also handles the game loop, running until the close() method is called. The game loop runs four main methods each frame:

    First drawFrame() handles the pre-rendering of all screen elements by recursively calling drawFrame(float, float, float, float, float) on each of the KitBits on the screen. drawFrame() also handles all of the rendering by instructing the GlooCore to renderFrame(int, int). This, in turn tells all GlooBatches to render all of their DrawingObjects to the RenderBuffer. This does not actually draw the rendered frame to the screen.

    calcFrame(double) is the first half of the update loop, which processes changes due to user input. This happens by calling calcFrame(double, Input) on the first Nook that is in focus. This ensures that Nooks are input blocking. If no such Nook exists, calcFrame is instead called on the Room of this GlooApplication. This, in turn, recursively gets called on any children of the Nook.

    stepFrame(double) is the second half of the update loop, which processes changes to all screen elements due to the passage of time between two frames. stepFrame(double) is first called on the Room of this GlooApplication, which recursively calls it on all screen elements, as all elements are descendants of the Room, in one way or another. Whereas calcFrame is not guaranteed to happen on a given element during a frame, stepFrame will happen every frame to every element.

    Finally glfwSwapBuffers(long) is called which actually draws the rendered frame to the screen. The number of nanoseconds in a frame is the FRAME_LENGTH variable, which can be set in the config file or through the GlooApplicationConfiguration class by specifying a framesPerSecond. Any spare time will simply be spent waiting, which will ensure a maximum number of frames per second. (No such guarantee is given for the minimum number of frames per second.

    Rendering happens primarily through the GlooCore, which handles everything from Textures to FontFamilies through GlooBatches. Multiple GlooApplications can be run at the same time by employing the runConcurrent(String, Consumer) method. See Driver.Main for an example implementation of running GlooApplications.

    Since:
    1.0

    • Constructor Detail

      • GlooApplication

        public GlooApplication(java.lang.String name)
        Creates a new GlooApplication given a name, which creates a GLFW window for the application with the specified configurations in the config file (which is the file with the name name.cfg). If the config file is empty, it creates a new config file. This defaults to specific configurations, which can be seen in the GlooApplicationConfiguration file.
        Parameters:
        name - String that will be displayed in the name bar at the top of the window. Title is also used to specify the config file, name.cfg

    • Method Detail

      • addChild

        public int addChild(KitBit newChild)
        Overrides the addChild(KitBit) method of KitBit to ensure that only one Room can be a child at a time. Nooks can still be added as desired, but all Nooks that are children of a Room will be removed if a different Room is added.

        Any added Nook will take any available slot or extend the list as necessary. Any Room added will be added in the same manner, but will immediately call the recursive destroy() method on the previously existing Room.

        Overrides:
        addChild in class KitBit
        Parameters:
        newChild - a KitBit that can be either a Room or Nook (or an extension thereof), but not anything else
        Returns:
        int the index of the child in the children list

      • calcFrame

        private void calcFrame(double delta)
        Replacement of the calcFrame(double, Input) method of KitBit. Calls calcFrame on only the first Nook that exists, is in focus, and is not a Room. If no Nooks are in focus, then calcFrame is called on the Room of this GlooApplication instead. In any case, calcFrame is eventually called on either one Nook or one Room.
        Parameters:
        delta - double for the number of seconds that have elapsed since the last calcFrame
        See Also:
        KitBit.checkFocus(Input)

      • calcFrame

        public void calcFrame(double delta,
                      Input input)
        Overrides the calcFrame(double, Input) method of KitBit to call the calcFrame(double) method of GlooApplication instead. This function should never be called and will spit out warnings if it is called, but will nonetheless call the correct function, which calls calcFrame on only the first Nook that exists, is in focus, and is not a Room. If no Nooks are in focus, then calcFrame is called on the Room of this GlooApplication instead. In any case, calcFrame is eventually called on either one Nook or one Room.
        Overrides:
        calcFrame in class KitBit
        Parameters:
        delta - double for the number of seconds that have elapsed since the last calcFrame
        input - an Input that does not actually get used
        See Also:
        calcFrame(double), KitBit.checkFocus(Input)

      • close

        public void close()
        Sets the complete boolean to true so that the game loop will exit.

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Overrides the destroy() method of KitBit to prevent the GlooApplication from trying to remove itself from its parent (it has none).
        Overrides:
        destroy in class KitBit

      • drawFrame

        private void drawFrame()
        Initiates the process of rendering to the screen.

        First calls on the drawFrame(float, float, float, float, float) method of Room to load the information necessary for rendering into arrays. This method recursively calls on all children to ensure that all KitBits prepare themselves for rendering.

        Then calls on the renderFrame(int, int) method of GlooCore to actually render to the screen. This method delegates the task of rendering to various GlooBatches. Rendering actually happens not directly to the screen but instead to a RenderBuffer. This gets rendered to the screen during the glfwSwapBuffers(long) call, which happens later in the game loop.

      • getApp

        public GlooApplication getApp()
        Gets this GlooApplication itself. This overrides the getApp() method of KitBit to prevent this GlooApplication from trying to ask its parent for its parent's GlooApplication, as this GlooApplication is already the one requested.
        Overrides:
        getApp in class KitBit
        Returns:
        this GlooApplication itself

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        GlooBatch of this application matching the given handle

      • getPool

        public Worker getPool()
        Gets the WorkerPool of this GlooApplication, which is the ThreadPool of the GlooCore. The WorkerPool is used to greatly expedite the process of pre-rendering through the power of multithreading!
        Returns:
        the WorkerPool(ThreadPool) of this GlooApplication for use in multithreading

        Overrides:
        ripChild in class KitBit
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • run

        public void run()

        Starts the Application by running the game loop, which will call drawFrame(), calcFrame(double), and stepFrame(double) every frame until told to stop. The three ways the game loop will exit are:

        1. An error occurs, printing a stacktrace and stopping the program
        2. The window is set to close by calling glfwWindowShouldClose(long) or
        3. The close() method of GlooApplication is called.
        It is preferred that the close() method be called instead of glfwWindowShouldClose(long).

        Every frame, four primary methods are called:

        1. drawFrame(), which handles pre-rendering and rendering, but does not draw directly to the screen
        2. calcFrame(double), which processes changes to screen elements due to user input
        3. stepFrame(double), which processes changes to all screen elements due to the passage of time between frames
        4. glfwSwapBuffers(long), which actually draws the rendered frame to the screen
        The game loop also keeps track of fps. If the amount of time it takes a frame to handle these methods in less than the number of nanoseconds in FRAME_LENGTH, then the thread sleeps for the remainder of time to ensure that there is a maximum fps. No such assurance can be given on minimum fps.

      • runConcurrent

        public static java.util.concurrent.Future runConcurrent(java.lang.String name,
                                                        java.util.function.Consumer<GlooApplication> setup)
        Spins off a new GlooApplication to run independently of a previously existing one in a new thread, given a name and a setup Consumer. The thread cleans itself up when the GlooApplication has finished running.
        Parameters:
        name - String that will be passed on to the GlooApplication constructor. This is the name of the window and of the config file, name.cfg
        setup - a Consumer that, while possibly any function whatsoever, typically is a function that specifies the Room that will initially be loaded.
        Returns:
        a Future used to monitor the state of the GlooApplication

      • stepFrame

        public void stepFrame(double delta)
        Overrides the stepFrame(double) method of KitBit to call stepFrame on only the Room of the GlooApplication, instead of all children. Since all KitBits are descendants of the Room in one way or another and the stepFrame(double) method of KitBit is recursive, stepFrame will eventually be called on all KitBits.
        Overrides:
        stepFrame in class KitBit
        Parameters:
        delta - double of the number of seconds between the previous frame and the current frame
        See Also:
        KitBit.calcFrame(double, Input)
